newsitem.title: USA: US money managers less bullish on US debt -- MCM.
newsitem.headline: US money managers less bullish on US debt -- MCM.

text.p: Fixed-income managers remained heavily invested in U.S. debt markets in the past week but reported a less bullish outlook, said the latest MCM MoneyWatch Inc asset allocation survey.
"This group (of investors) is playing the broader range," said MCM money market analyst Peter McTeague. "They are less bullish."
The weekly survey showed durations as a percentage of benchmark rose to 105.7 percent in the week ended September 3 from 105.6 percent in the prior week.

A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market. A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 20 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," down from 22 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" rose to 24 percent, up from 19 percent in the week ended August 26.
Fifty-six percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market, down from 59 percent a week ago.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 3.10 percent, against 3.12 percent registered the previous week.

The survey showed 28 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, down from 32 percent in the previous week, while 42 percent underweighted it. The remaining 30 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 33 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 20 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants, who manage about $90.0 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM.
